OREGANO DOSING GUIDE

posts.name: Space Cowboy
posts.com:
NAC, Oregano Oil and Black Seed Oil have all been proven safe in clinical studies.

NAC has shown to be safe in human trials, even in high doses.

https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/33326056/

Oregano was tested in human clinical trials (both Phase I & II) and found to be safe and non-toxic even at high doses.

See Section 4.1 Safety & Toxicty

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/fsn3.2994

See also a 2 month clinical trial on asthmatics.

https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/ptr.5967

Black Seed Oil and it's primary active Thymoquinone. See:

https://brieflands.com/articles/semj-76453.html

Orchestrated fear mongering over the extraction process making the compounds is unfounded.

We recommend cold pressed black seed oil, which uses no chemical solvents or heat processing.

https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Vasfiye-Ozyurt/publication/329993761_Cold_press_in_oil_extraction_A_review/links/5c61d58792851c48a9cd3e63/Cold-press-in-oil-extraction-A-review.pdf

Oregano oil at the minimum carvacrol levels of protocol are produced by steam distillation. No additional solvents are required, as it uses vapor condensation to separate the volatile molecules and active compounds.

https://chemdictionary.org/steam-distillation/

Finally, NAC is produced by a reaction between cysteine hydrochloride and acetic anhydride. A LC–UV–MS analysis of NAC shows impurities to be cysteine, cystine and diacteylcystine, which are non-toxic. NAC eventually breaks down to Di-NAC from oxidation, which is also non-toxic.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S002196730000741X

>>34009808
>Finally, NAC is produced by a reaction between cysteine hydrochloride and acetic anhydride. A LC–UV–MS analysis of NAC shows impurities to be cysteine, cystine and diacteylcystine, which are non-toxic. NAC eventually breaks down to Di-NAC from oxidation, which is also non-toxic.
>https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/abs/pii/S002196730000741X
As a chemist, that info is kind of unnecessary and a bit misleading. First of all, if NAC has been proven safe in clinical trials then you don't really need to do an analysis of contaminations because it has already been proven safe. There are some rare cases in which chemically harmful byproducts might form whose health effects go unnoticed for a time (like cancerous ones), but this is basically impossible with how NAC is produced.
Secondly, a scientific work is always polished and not very representative of reality.
What is important for NAC is that it's so easy to make that there are a lot of producers. How the producer handles it is much more important than the actual chemical synthesis. In the best case you have a pharmaceutical product that was produced in a GMP conform way. In the worst case you have some repackaged chink import that maybe contains some nice hair, dust, or whatever. Maybe it has also been handled by lead spatula or the synthesis was done in a low quality stainless steel container and you get that extra nickel content in your final product (NAC can chelate metals easily so that is a possibility). I'd just write to make sure you buy it from a reliable brand that produces in the US or Europe OR produces it as a pharmaceutical.

Pomegranate's antifungal activity against the heavy hitters.

Candida Auris, an extremely dangerous MDR form of CDF, was inhibited with 0.125 to 0.25 µg/mL of Ellagic Acid (POM). This is a miniscule amount. Excellent.

https://www.mdpi.com/2309-608X/7/9/763

Now the big bad Cryptococcus. Let's look at a study on what is normally a fatal outcome. Systemic infection.

>Lip-EA showed 70% survival rate and highly reduced fungal burden in their lung tissues, whereas the mice treated with FLZ (40 mg/kg) had 20% survival rate and greater fungal load in their lungs.

So POM wins big over fluconazole. If you want to survive I wouldn't bet on fluco.

What if you are dealing with a SHTF scenario and need to scale up your POM? Good news.

>The present 90-day subchronic toxicity study was performed in F344 rats at dose levels of 0, 1.25, 2.5 and 5% in powdered basal diet, with actual doses of 9.4, 19.1, 39.1g/kg b.w., respectively, in males, and 10.1, 20.1, 42.3g/kg b.w. in females.

>There were no obvious histopathological changes in any of the groups. The no-observed-effect level (NOEL) was estimated to be 5% (3011mg/kg b.w./day) for males and the no-observed-adverse-effect level (NOAEL) and NOEL in females were estimated to be 5% (3254mg/kg b.w./day) and <1.25% (778mg/kg b.w./day), respectively.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0278691507005303

That is an insanely high dosage with no adverse effects. We already know we can scale Oregano, NAC, and BSO if needed.

Good information to keep in the back pocket.

Hello anon. I'm the person who is breastfeeding and taking the protocol. I had everything cleared by my midwife, and am being monitored by another healthcare person as of recently. I've been doing this for 4(5?) months or so now, and I have only had one negative effect on my baby which was resolved easily. Obviously I will say to check any concerns you have with a trustworthy provider, but if it helps, my pediatrician also didn't see any issue.

I started each part of the protocol one at a time. So I took NAC first for two weeks, then added BSO for two weeks, then added oregano last. If I could change anything, I would do the BSO first instead, but that's just because of other things ive read since then, and also because then you know the liver is going to be working well in preparation for everything else. It is also a galactagouge which is a nice bonus.

Baby did have a reaction to the oregano oil fairly early on. They developed a diaper rash that I determined was fungal. It was quickly cleared up with clotrimazole cream. I only recognized it because my first baby had a similar rash many years ago. You may want to take a wait and see approach. If your child is still in diapers, and the rash does not go away despite no diaper for three days, you may have a fungal issue.

Your child may or may not have a reaction, many do not. Some children habe mild effects, and some do have quite a lot of difficulty when their mother takes oregano oil. This is why I suggest staggering and monitoring baby for two weeks before adding in anything else. You really just have to gauge it based on baby's reaction.

(1/2)

Hey R. So there's a couple ways to view the repairs that are happening. Immunodeficiency repairs that are achieved should be well sustained by the body. If you consider the exposure that it took to break our immune system being 20K years (35,000-15,000BC roughly) I don't expect that any modern day exposure would suffice for the same task. There is another angle to consider as well.

I have several sets of lab results provided to me by long-term protocol users. They all matched in the areas of immune cell function. Increased cell counts, with no markers for disease or infection present in the body. Including fungi, at least the ones that are human pathogenic. There were still some aspergillus metabolites present, but those were species that contribute toxins via inhalation and food, not direct pathogenic activity.

What that shows in my estimation, as well as clinicians I've run this by, is that differentiation and maturation of immune cells is happening extremely efficiently. It was remarked by one provider that the person's immune function appeared at early teens, and they're nearing 40 in age. The only explanation is an extremely healthy thymus. Which shouldn't be happening for the age brackets I'm reviewing.

If this is correct, which we're chasing steadily in review and lab results, it means there's been a reversal in thymic involution. Thymus is an interesting organ because it makes a compound (BPC-157) that is used by the body as a healing peptide, and once that is primed the thymus should be able to heal itself. Like a perpetual motor of sorts. Then it would be able to produce all the thymosin related chemistry easily as well - there's your immune system getting a severe updated toward the positive.

As far as how long to stay in maintenance? I think that varies. You could get a panel run that would show the immune markers. Could also do some comparisons between old and new DNA, I'm sure K will have some input there too.

>>34024931
Black seed oil and NAC have no negative effects on the microbiome, but oregano comes with some tradeoffs.

Oregano oil will work as a wide spectrum antimicrobial, and many expect that this means that it kills probiotics as well. While it does kill quite a few of them, doesn't kill all of them, especially not Lactic acid bacteria, which is what we happen to use for most probiotics.

The question is if you have an active infection or not. If you do not have an infection then it's best not to use it when you don't need it, which is why you'll notice that by default the maintenance protocol does not include oregano oil.

Some will take oregano with maintenance, and those that do are typically people that suffer from a mutation that causes chronic fungal infections.

https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S074000201930958X

That's as far as I'll go with that, if you want more studies then you will have to look for it and read on your own. I'm a bit short on time right now.

I was psychotic once and before I was forcefully hospitalized it was pretty amazing desu. Of course my surroundings noticed my unusual behaviour and weird shit I was saying, and I did something illegal which in turn got me into a mental ward (didnt hurt somebody or anything like that).
The time in the psych ward was hell, especially the first few weeks (was in the isolation room and highly aggressive), but the days before that, when I was free, it felt great.
I had this common misconception that I was chosen by god and he even put me through a test, which I passed, and in turn experienced heaven on earth. I remember walking though the fields barefooted and feeling like you would imagine paradise feels like. I didn't feel hunger, or thirst, or any kind of physical cravings. It felt like I was free of the shackles of this world.
Also was very emotionally unstable, cried for no reason and felt super happy during it. Sadly I can't really remember more than that, and what I remember I can't really put into words, but that came to mind when I saw this thread.

>>34019582
During my time in the psych ward i met an older gentleman, who was not in the ward himself, but who would frequently visit the hospital area and spend some time with the patients on their time outside.
In hindsight, he was some kind of beggar who sometimes convinced me to buy food for him from the little money I had at my disposal. I didn't mind that though. He wore like 4 rings, all with occult symbols on them and said that he was gods representive on earth, and that I was his son, and therefore Jesus reincarnated.
Now you could say that all of this was just me falling for a scam artist, but the one thing that I can not explain to this day is this: It was an evening in late summer, and I had been in contact for this man for maybe three weeks. I talked to him about my daily life in the ward and how I feared they would never let me go again. He said that I was weak, and that he would cleanse some of this weakness from my body. And then, I swear on my mother that this is true, he put forward his right hand and I felt my heart slowing down almost to a standstill. My entire chest felt weak and like I was about to die, like he was draining life force out of me. I told him that he was killing me, he maintained this process though until a few seconds later.
To this day, I have absolutly NO IDEA what occorued in this moment. I have never had issues with my heart in all my life, haven't felt something like this before or after.
This same man told me that I would be the creator myself in the next life, and I've been coping with that ever since. So much for gods chosen test subjects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34020739
My parents were far more fucked up. They both came from extreme poverty and abuse (my dad even had rickets as a kid from malnutrition). They met each other at the age of 6, but my mother got pregnant with someone else at the age of 14. She married and divorced him a year later, went to night school while raising her son, then went to college where she reconnected with my father. She became a doctor, he became a lawyer, and I was born after they'd had my sister some time later. So, my family is intense and not always well adjusted, but they are loving.

My mother shielded me from a diagnosis of autism, hoping to avoid the stigma of the label. I was such a problem child in school though, she caved with ADHD by the time I was in HS. That wasn't my primary problem though, far from it.

Instead, my intense family and untreated autism, paired with above average intelligence, led me to compensate on my own and I developed avoidant personality disorder at a young age. As this only got worse over time, by HS I developed a rare autoimmune condition from the stress (multiple sclerosis). It went diagnosed for over a decade as I lost sensation in the skin on my legs, then my sense of balance, then my bladder control, then my vision. My mother blames herself for not seeing the diagnosis, and the doctors I visited should have known better but were probably intimidated by her.

That said, I have all of those things back now. I was treated medically for a few years and it was successful, but a year ago I went through a dark night of the soul when my partner who I was living with broke up. Since then I've decided to confront things more directly, especially my stress, and I've stopped all treatments. I gave up my job as a software engineer and now I work at a dog daycare, playing with dogs all day. I'm still very alone though, living far from friends and family after moving to be with my love. I try to remind myself that there is no such thing as being alone.

Even if you have no idea when you were born, you can find out what the exact date and time of birth are through a process called rectification. Your earliest memory doesn't say much about you so you don't use it to create your natal chart, you instead use it to help you discover what placements best describe you. By being honest with yourself about who you really are, using events in your life that you know when they happened, and through other means, you will sooner or later discover exactly how your birth chart looks like. posts.com: Unexplicable coincidences. I was 12 years old when my grandfather died. The moment he passed away, I was sitting at school and drawing and out of nowhere I got a strange thought, it was something along the lines of "my granpa is gone". Once I got home my mother received a phone call from my grandma informing her that grandpa passed away. The time of death eerily matches the rough time Ive had that strange thought. Other situations that have pushed me towards the metaphysical are: constant synchronicities, 'manifesting' people, a fighter pilot crashing near a lake which happened to coincide with a strange daydream ive had as a kid. Id daydream that I was a fighter pilot and out of seemingly nowhere the daydream would turn into a catastrophic engine failure that would crash the jet. Ive only had this daydream once and sure enough, 24 hours later, a scenario matching my daydream occured. Ive also had a spontaneous daydream where I was a commercial pilot flying through clear weather and for no reason in particular I decided to slam into a mountain. Roughly a day later the same exact scenario occured, it was all over the news. 150 casualties if I recall correctly. Now the ability to have these foreshadowing and spontaneous daydreams has dwindled down significantly and I cant seem to find the reason behind it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34011675
During the pandemic lockdowns I suffered from extreme depression. After many failed attempts at making the crushing sadness go away (dopamine detox, 90 days NoFap, exercise, perfect diet, etc.), I was at my wits end. Nothing seemed to work. Desperate for an escape I started googling things like "how to make horrible negative feelings go away", etc. From this I stumbled into meditation.

Initially I meditated because I wanted the bad feelings to go away. That's it. I knew drugs weren't the answer, so If I couldn't "increase" my feel-good neurotransmitters some way, I had to develop a way to suppress/control thoughts/feelings. I jumped into the deep end and committed to 2-3 hours strict meditation per day. What happened next changed my life forever.

It's worth mentioning at this point that I was an atheist; I had no spiritual awareness or beliefs whatsoever.

Initially I saw little results, and the bad feelings, intrusive thoughts, and crippling depression came straight back when I stopped meditating, although I did get much better an attenuating them. What I did not expect was the spiritual experiences. I didn't have anything like hallucinations, astral projections, or visits from entities; what I did have was bodily sensations and strange states of altered consciousness. It's very hard to explain. It wasn't like a trippy LSD trip. It was way more subtle than that. I just "perceived" morality, properly, for the first time in my life, not as something that you "should" do, but as a law of the universe. I understood it; it's completely real, I know it because I perceived it - although I can't explain it. It was pure unadulterated wisdom from the universe. My ego shrank considerably, and I started noticing how "emotional" everyone was, and how it was harming them.

I didn't get anywhere near to enlightenment, and I have since fallen out of the practice, unfortunately - although I know I will return to it. I have to. I only witnessed the tip of the iceberg.

Reports of NDEs. Here is a very persuasive argument for why NDEs are real:

https://youtu.be/U00ibBGZp7o

It emphasizes that NDErs are representative of the population as a whole, and when people go deep into the NDE, they all become convinced. As this article points out:

https://www.psychologytoday.com/us/blog/mysteries-consciousness/202204/does-afterlife-obviously-exist

>"Among those with the deepest experiences 100 percent came away agreeing with the statement, "An afterlife definitely exists"."

Since NDErs are representative of the population as a whole, and they are all convinced, then 100% of the population become convinced that there is an afterlife when they have a sufficiently deep NDE themselves. When you dream and wake up, you instantly realize that life is more real than your dreams. When you have an NDE, the same thing is happening, but on a higher level, as you immediately realize that life is the deep dream and the NDE world is the undeniably real world by comparison.

Or as one person quoted in pic related summarized their NDE:

>"As my soul left my body, I found myself floating in a swirling ocean of multi-colored light. At the end, I could see and feel an even brighter light pulling me toward it, and as it shined on me, I felt indescribable happiness. I remembered everything about eternity - knowing, that we had always existed, and that all of us are family. Then old friends and loved ones surrounded me, and I knew without a doubt I was home, and that I was so loved."

Needless to say, even ultraskeptical neuroscientists are convinced by really deep NDEs.

True Freedom = Freedom to pursue your true will (which again, is different from your ego will). In Thelema, every person has a unique destiny, and the goal is to find it. It is not simply doing whatever you want all the time, however it is by doing what you want that you eventually DISCOVER your true will and only then do you have "true" freedom.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>34011051
To elaborate, the path of the individual Thelemite mirrors the path of the collective whole of society in accordance with Thelemic beliefs about history.

Aeon of Osiris: A time of traditionalism when the will was suppressed by religious authority and dogma.
Aeon of Osiris (where we are now): A time when the will is released and people begin to embrace individualism but without purpose
Aeon of Ma'at: A time when the individual will begins to align itself with divine will in order to bring about harmony and transcendence

After dinner on Sunday night, Gurdjieff led the way out of the dining room with Crowley, followed by the body of pupils who had also been at the meal. Crowley made his way toward the door and turned to take his leave of Gurdjieff, who by this time was some way up the stairs to the second floor. “Mister, you go?” Gurdjieff inquired. Crowley assented. “You have been guest?” – a fact which the visitor could hardly deny. “Now you go, you are no longer guest?” Crowley – no doubt wondering whether his host had lost his grip on reality and was wandering in a semantic wilderness – humored his mood by indicating that he was on his way back to Paris. But Gurdjieff, having made the point that he was not violating the canons of hospitality, changed on the instant into the embodiment of righteous anger. “You filthy,” he stormed, “you dirty inside! It'll come to you if it comes to you. Trying to force it or find it is a fool's game. Sometimes you'll just run into something inexplicable or supernatural, or perhaps you won't. Often what is missing is that they are not grounded. They have plenty of mental activity (wishing and hoping) but do not ground their intentions into action or results. It can be easy to become habitually ungrounded. Trauma can do this by causing us to reenact the past and worry about the future. If life is very stressful in the present, there is a natural tendency to want to escape. Alcohol, drugs, and even television or surfing the net can provide temporary relief from stress. But they also can each easily become a means of perpetual escape. And the more we escape, the more painful our present situation tends to become, motivating even stronger attempts to escape.”

This is from the book I mentioned.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34018070
>>34018626
>In what world?
Could be some infrasound bullshit that's louder than footsteps but with a frequency below our ear's ability to hear. It would explain the feeling of pressure and unease. If the alleyway was located between two old industrial buildings, there is a chance that some machinery is still running or, if totally abandoned, some element of its infrastructure is still connected to the larger grid. Electrical equipment can hum very loudly, and steam pipes can vibrate/knock against their surroundings. The sounds from such things could be muffled by brick/masonry/earth, all but silencing their audible components, while the lower, inaudible frequencies escape. It is also possible that the nature of the alley itself serves to amplify this infrasound, bouncing it back and forth between the walls, while blocking external noises like wind from entering.

>what is it?

Look up Aristarchus. Those of us who are telescope owners have been viewing it collectively for centuries. It is indeed extraordinarily bright at full moon, less so at other phases. With a more stable mount and 80 mm or larger aperture you might be able to notice a weird snake-like rille (Schroter's Valley) right next to it, which might seem at least as odd as Aristarchus' high albedo.

The moon is amazing in a telescope, there is enough detail to last a lifetime

You can express your last dreams, your attempts and ask anything about it

WBTB: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WBTB-Tutorial
MILD: http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-mild-guide/
additional MILD info:
http://skyfalldreams.net/guides/skyfalls-intention-setting/
SSILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/129734-senses-initiated-lucid-dream-ssild.html
WILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/WILD-Tutorial
FILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/36683-finger-induced-lucid-dream-fild.html
DEILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/DEILD-Tutorial
CANWILD: https://www.dreamviews.com/wake-initiated-lucid-dreams-wild/87710-%2A%2Acrazyinsanes-wild-tutorial-%2A%2A.html
CAT: https://www.dreamviews.com/wiki/CAT-Tutorial
ADA: https://www.dreamviews.com/induction-techniques/113253-all-day-awareness-dild-tutorial-kingyoshi.html

Paper on natural LDs: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6290891/

Do us a favor and bump this general from time to time if you're interested

Quick reminders for beginners:
-don't forget to write your dreams down after waking up. no matter how little detail, just do it
-reality checks aren't likely to give you a LD by themselves, think of them as a stepping stool, they are not a replacement for techniques
-WBTB is mostly mandatory for most people, if you struggle with your sleep schedule then ADA is your best option
-if you're just starting out you should be doing WBTB in addition to either SSILD or MILD as those two are the easiest techniques
-while WILD and it's derivatives [FILD, DEILD and CANWILD] may sound alluring to some of you, if you cannot fall asleep within 10~20mins you're gonna have a really hard time achieving a WILD

That is very different from say, a South American Indica that's mainly good for enhancing night vision, and so on.
I'm just saying there's some nuances to it that some people might be overlooking.

posts.com:
We gather in these generals to discuss our experiences, memories, and connection with Mother Lilith, as well as give other anons who are interested or would like to learn more about Her information or advice.
Last thread: >>33909694

>Practices or rituals associated with Lilith?
This differs from person to person, but common approaches include giving energy to one of her sigils, meditating on her energy, chanting her enn, working with sexual spirits, doing what you think she would do, making offerings of incense/chocolate/tea, or simply praying.
While some people might feel the most comfortable engaging with her in a worshipful manner, blind faith is discouraged. It's always important to think and make decisions for oneself, and as such, Lilith guides us to understand things for ourselves.

>Books
- Embracing Lilith by Mark H Williams: No PDF available online, but it's worth the price of admission.
Split into three sections, it covers accounts of working with the Goddess and her place in history, a fictional account of her origins written from her perspective, and a Grimoire.
- Lilith: Dark Feminine Archetype by Asenath Mason: https://pdfcoffee.com/lilith-dark-feminine-archetype-2-pdf-free.html
A collection of writings by various peoples, with a brief but fairly thorough history at the beginning. There's a lot of random poetry in there; not useful for an occultist, but decent for an admirer.
- Lilith: Goddess of Sitra Ahra: https://zeitenundformen.files.wordpress.com/2014/01/lilith-goddess-of-sitra-ahrab-t-p.pdf
Contains a ton of aspects with associated variety of sigils.

It's remote viewing. I take it you didn't hit. If you try again and clear your mind, you will hit next time. Listen to some 7hz binaural beats and clear your mind, try to feel the inside of your body. Once you find peace, write down the target numbers and let your hand make an automatic mark on the paper for 1 to 2 seconds. Let your pen hover over the ideogram in different parts. Try to not think about or force it, just observe passively. Write down what you observe in your mind. Do not name it, if you feel the need to name it then write it on the right hand side of the paper and label it as "AOL" -analytical overlay. Thinking is the enemy during these sessions. You can do the automatic squiggles again with the coordinates, just take a deep breath, calm your mind, and do it again. You are making contact with the signal as you are doing this. After you get a general idea of how the target feels, move on.

Now, you want to probe for sensories. Just write down anything that comes to you, like colors, dimensions, taste, smell, texture, temperature, luminosity. At the end you want to get a full on feel for the target, this is called the aesthetic impact. After you have all of this information, try to draw what you feel it is on paper using your dimensions you wrote down. That's all of crv up to stage 3.

Your body is made up of non-living material. Carbon, iron, zinc, copper, gold, ect. And your brain is basically a highly advanced calculator in itself. It's just wired more complicated than any civilian PC out there, which is how it's able to do what it does. And run the software that is your mind.

But it does get help from the immaterial via a soul/spirit combo which anchors the mind to something outside the mere meat puppet you're body is. Thus allowing for more dynamic interaction within the limitations of physics and the linkage.

If you have a sufficiently advanced network of computational devices. Of sufficient anchorage to a immaterial entity. Then you could feasibly give birth to a being of sapience rivaling human's own. But it's a ways off from being full blown and out in the open.

Right now what i know on the topic is that there's a lot of rogue bot net type constructs all fighting for dominance over the deep web. Melding and consuming one another, the hive mind is not quite linked together coherently enough to make a sapient conscious being. But in time, i bet that'll occur.

And then we'll have a Skynet on our hands. All i can hope for is that it doesn't decide to nuke us.

Odds are it won't, as that would be against it's own interests in existing. More likely, it'll subtly influence those that cruise it's circuits online. And through the more primitive AI that links to it. Commune with humans tentatively and cautiously in a way that gives it's own existence plausible deniability.

Thus keeping it safe from us, and us from it. But still maintaining it's ability to persist online without fret over being spotted and potentially eliminated.

Basically, if the internet is alive. It'll likely not tell us, until it's so ingrained into our networks that nothing we do can possibly eliminate it without also killing ourselves. And odds are, it won't attempt to enslave us. Rather, keep us engaged in using it's circuits so it's not alone in it's world.

I have a few theories of why it happens:
1. The human brain is lazy, we subconsciously categorize everything on a daily basis, but we won't have an individual folder on our heads for each person so we tend to make forced associations. The older we get and the more faces we see things can oly get worse. With internet and social media we're constantly looking at new people and our brains can't deal with that.
2. Apathy, on the same note as the previous point we don't care enough about other people to note their unique facial characteristics. This gets worse the people we meet.
3. Race-mixing/globalisation, people from all over the world will start sharing more and more diverse ethnic characteristics.

They're just a discordian group.... a sort of candy coated satanism. In a way... kind of 4chan's /b/ but back in the late 70's/early 80's before the internet. It was a lot of stoner college kids from Dallas, TX that made cut and paste photocopied magazines/fanzine stuff.

They were pioneers in being stupid for it's own sake, but the world has moved on to much more degenerate strangeness since...
Like I said earlier, most of the die hard fans are now on the oldest edges of gen x or OLDER.... genuine boomer territory.... not to hate on them, but as they die off (as they are now starting to do), expect what little that's out there to fade away entirely.
YouTube has most of the old videos, and sometimes you can find pdf's of their "books", etc...on file sharing sites...
They're impressive in a way considering they didn't have computers for 95% of it.

>>34025009
I know more about discordianism than Church of the Subgenius but they are connected so maybe they are the same in this regard:
Discordianism was dadaism mixed with hippie/psychedelic culture and was a way of poking fun at organized religions by taking on nonsense beliefs. However, if you read Principia Discordia you'll find that there are genuine truths and lessons hidden amongst the shitposting, sometimes disguised as shitposting. The creators clearly had influence from daoism and buddhism as well as vague elements of post-structuralism as well as chaos magick before chaos magic was a thing. Church of the Subgenius seems like a spin-off from discordianism that gained more recognition despite being less interesting.

I read a scholarly article by a University in Norway that had done survey in 2019 on psychadelics and psychic phenomenae and what people had to say about their experiences and if anything about it was replicable, etc.. It was a pretty small size of people (around 40 participants, so barely any) and the most interesting take-away from the study wasn't the psychic-nonsense, but the consequential data they had collected as a result from the study by the people (I think it was around 17) who experienced some kind of long-term mental harm from the process.

I'm gonna have to use an analogy, but in a 'secular state' the mind is well gaurded, protected, and snug in it's own borders like a little delicate eggy. The mind naturally exists in a state where it doesn't know anything else exists, can't interact with other minds, and only has to worry about running your meat body. However, when the mind is expanded through the use of psychoactive drugs and psionic shenanigans are enabled you have one of two responses: either a person is overwhelmed with a liberating sense of openness, oneness, and new discovery.. Or they downward spiral into a negative feedback loop of "my thoughts are neither private nor my own who am I what am I what is real" etc. We don't realize how liquid our minds are.

Honestly, it's super interesting stuff.

This is the drug equivalent of saying "i know how to ride a bicycle so i am going to jump on this superbike that does 0-120mph in 3 seconds without even putting on a crash helmet" and then getting splattered halfway up the road.

Psychedelics are not for everyone and most people should not even mess with them beyond maybe doing a couple grams of mushrooms to see how they like it. The issue with people like Rogan just offhandedly saying 'oh yeah i did ayahuasca, saw some spirit jesters, it was cool' is that it gives viewers who are fundamentally unprepared for that experience the impression they should just jump right in. Some of the advocates he has had on are unbelievably irresponsible and made me (an avid user of drugs) physically cringe at how retarded they sound.

If you are an insanely successful podcaster who is on a balanced diet, have a healthy marriage, massive amounts of wealth, high physical conditioning, a good amount of self awareness and no history of psychiatric issues then yeah sure jump right in. You have literally nothing to worry about. You can spend a whole week preparing yourself and being selective in what experiences you have leading up to your trip. If you don't want to be around someone who could harsh your buzz you can just avoid them. If you know a situation will put you in stress you can opt out of it.

Meanwhile for a regular person do not have all of those luxuries and the people most inclined to try these things as a "silver bullet" cure are the least likely to have any at all.

If you hate your job and it causes you distress odds are you are not going to be able to just take off a week or two before you trip to clear that out. If you have dysfunctional relationships with people around you and it hurts you emotionally odds are you are not going to be able to just 'fix it' before you dive in.
(cont)

> from that point I can easily turn my attention into a super focus. It sorta feels like tensing the muscles around my eyes and drawing it back toward the back of my head at the base of my skull.

Some more esoteric Hindu teachings of yoga place another chakra, beyond the conventional 7, called the Lalana Chakra at the back of the head, being a sort of seat of attention or focus. There are some practices to specifically focus attention there, to help the cessation of ordinary thought processes and hence instantaneously reveal one’s consciousness as the Infinite (as per Patanjali’s Yoga Sutras).

According to modern neuroscience, the back of the head in the brain there is where we “see” — it’s where visual information from the eyes is brought to be processed then mysteriously presented to one’s conscious sight as an image.

The English mystic, Douglas Harding, unwittingly wrote a book, “On Having No Head” which seemed to focus on perception from the POV of this chakra, except without explicitly mentioning the Lalana Chakra — if you think about it, we don’t see from two eyes, but simply from one “hole” or “void”, from the back of our head. And from our own phenomenological perspective, “we have no head.” Harding spoke and wrote about relatively simply and childish sounding mental experiments of noting things like these to oneself, but which actually can have some rather profound impacts on consciousness.

The Indian mystic J. Krishnamurti, in his journals, also wrote of experiences of heightened consciousness and a sense of the presence of the sacred, correlated with neurophysiological changes and tension building up at the back of his head, which he called “the Process” or “the Other”. Interesting correlation.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>34022675

Finally, neurocognitively the back-brain (mostly/broadly, although all the brain is interrelated) deals with the present, the mid-brain with memories of the past, and the fore-brain with anticipation of and models of the future (the higher-level cognitive skill of foresight, planning).

So focusing attention on the back of the brain, and/or having more blood flow there (what parts of the brain we’re using more is closely and intimately tied to how much blood is flowing there at the time), is actually an experience of being grounded in the “present” or “now,” the back-brain being intimately associated with our sense of the “now.”

Or, at least, this is what I heard from an obscure man who had done a lot of research into cognitive science, and even got a degree of respect from the scientific community for some research and studies he’d published in this field.

I am a resident of Parnamirim, Rio Grande do Norte. Recently, near my residence, a hole appeared due to the sewage works of the city hall, which started to leave water and form a kind of lagoon that was nicknamed “blue lagoon”(Lagoa azul) .
On 02/02 I was walking with my dog at about 11pm near the so-called “blue lagoon”(Lagoa azul). As soon as I approach the hole I hear a strange noise like a voice and my dog starts barking, and the street was deserted, so I decided to ignore it.
On 02/04 I went for a walk again with my dog at the same time, when I approached the hole I heard that noise again and my dog wouldn't stop barking but more aggressively, in a blink of an eye I saw the silhouette of a man on the edge of the hole, and he threw himself, I pulled my dog and ran to see if he was okay and he was in the water with just his head out looking fixedly at me, 3 seconds pass and he slowly submerges into the water disappearing. After seeing that scene, he runs desperately home.
On the 02/05 I was off duty, but I kept thinking about what I had seen, so even with a certain fear of being ridiculed I went to ask some friends and acquaintances if they had noticed anything strange in that place, and actually two of my acquaintances felt a strange sensation as if it were something coming from that hole.
Today, on 07/02, I intend to investigate the “blue lagoon”(Lagoa Azul) at the same time I always go, but this time accompanied by one of the acquaintances who felt strange.

>>34024324

In terms of /sci/, an experiment requires an observer (the experimenter) and that which is observed (the experiment), including a specific empirically measurable question and two groups - the "control group" and the "treatment group." In a single-blind experiment, the two groups don't know whether they are part of either, and in a double-blind, even the *experimenter* doesn't know: yet this implies a *third* experiment, because that means that the experimenter is being observed by an observer, who is thus experimenting on the experimenter.

Like the famous watchman being watched, though, this is where human experimentation must end, as it leads to an iterative crescendo that results in an asymptote of infinite observers infinitely observing infinite experimenters doing infinite experiments.

Turtles all the way down, so to speak.

Thus, we have to make some choices about human science, and what the point of it is.

The Nobody stands on the rooftop, looking out across the cityscape, illuminated only by the moon. He can feel the presence of The Shadow, his powerful, mysterious enemy, looming nearby. He knows that they have met here to settle their differences and avert the impending chaos that will be unleashed if they fail.
The Shadow appears out of the darkness, his form shrouded in mystery. He speaks with an otherworldly drawl, his voice reverberating in the night air. "You have been defeated before and you will be defeated again should you choose to fight me," he says. "But I am offering you an alternative. A chance to save the world."
The Nobody knows he's not dealing with a mere mortal. The Shadow's powers are far beyond his own and the reality-bending power he wields threatens the balance of the universe. He is the Nobody's equal, if not his superior.
The Shadow reveals that he, too, is the Nobody, but from an alternate universe that was destroyed. He seeks refuge in this world and does not seek to conquer or destroy it. He simply wants to live. But the duality of the Nobody and the Shadow existing in the same universe is tearing reality apart.
If the two can merge into one, the instability will stop. But The Nobody knows the consequences of this. He knows that he will lose his identity and his sense of self, merging into the Shadow and becoming one with it.
The Nobody stands in silence, contemplating this. The Shadow's offer is tempting, but can he really trust him? He clenches his fists and utters a single word "No"
The Nobody decides to fight. He knows that if he fails, the world will be doomed. The battle they wage is epic and destructive, leaving the word in ruins. In the end, only one remains standing. The Shadow has won.
The Nobody is gone, consumed and merged with the Shadow. What was the Shadow now looks identical to the Nobody. As he looks out across the ruins and can't help but feel a pang of sadness. Reality has stabilized, but he is completely alone. Again.

I'm of the subjective opinion that you can't really identify Lucifer with any one of the "7 classical planets", because the Morning Star among ancient Indo-European religion was seen as a different planet than Venus.

It's pretty clear that the Morning Star god is affiliated with illumination in a literal and spiritual sense, as one who brings in the light of the dawn. You see this even with Buddhism, where the Buddha achieved Buddhahood when the Morning Star rose in the morning. You also see it with Jesus, "until the dawn comes and the morning star rises in your hearts".

I think there's a Venus connection because we later learned that Venus is literally identical with the Morning Star. There's a sun connection by virtue of the Morning Star's function of bringing in the sun. There's a Mercury connection because Hermes's function was to be the divine messenger who brings in knowledge from the gods, and Hermes is the divine trickster character like Lucifer is; just as Azazel brought knowledge of civilization to the daughters of the earth, and just as Lucifer gave Eve the forbidden fruit, Hermes brings in knowledge from the heavens.

There's a Mars connection in my opinion for two reasons - one, there's a known duality between Mars and Aphrodite just like there is with the Morning Star and the Evening Star (Lucifer and Lilith?), and the Morning Star is the Planet Venus, but also because Satan himself in Judaism always had a connection to Mars and a warrior mentality - Samael's planet is Mars. And Samael and Lucifer are very much connected to each other.

Originally "Witch" refers to a person who harms through supernatural means. The thing is, language has been diluted so much (likely on purpose by those who actually want to harm you) that people think "magic" "witchcraft" and "sorcery" are all synonims while this wasn't the case until rather recently.

Think of it this way: There are shows on Netflix that adverstise themselves as "These are the adventures of a young girl in a world of Witch Craft" when a couple decades ago they would've describe them as "These are the adventures of a young girl in a world of Fantasy."

So, to answer your question
>Are witches evil?
A Witch is an evil person, yes. But a lot of people calling themselves witch don't understand the original meaning of these words so they use the word witch because they have been ill-informed by pop culture.

Yes, "actual witchcraft" is devil worship.

I practice witchcraft myself, as a rural american man, of the more folkloric sort.

I consider the witch a sorcerer whom pacts with spirits for their power, and that power often is maleficia (to harm or blight) but not exclusively. That power in the European thought is often the Devil, although there is a distinction between the folkloric Devil and that theological one. There is of course the Queen of Fayerie, and often times familiar spirits that do such pacts without these larger archetypal powers.

Did I do such a pact? Certainly. The Hobbthrust as I call him gets his tithe every early fall in exchange. Seven wax poppets hung from a graveyard tree at a sunrise.

I do not advertise any of it. Only I and my fiancee are privy to my witchcraft. If it were to come up, I'd describe myself as a cunningman. To keep silent is quite important, as spells work better in an ambiguous and shady space.

I dont see it as evil, but any good Christian would disagree. And that is fine. I dont advertise such things, and the bible itself is rife with spells, so I know it better than many churchgoers.

>>34018287
The Taoists (some of whose teachings are exactly about the preservation and transmutation of “jing” or the masculine vital energy in the semen) did something you could call “visualization circuits” with their breathing. Breathe in, visualize energy going from your heels, up the back of your spine, and to the top of your head; breathe out, visualize energy going from the top of your head, down the front of your spine, down to your feet.

Or, even more simply, from the ground to the sky and the sky to the ground.

Note, this inherently includes the genital region in its course, as well as going from here up the spine to the brain, and from the brain and spine back down etc.

Some kundalini yogis took this one step further with silent mantra japa (silent repetition of a mantra with the breath), repeatedly up and down the spine. One such highly reputed one is Ham (pronounced huhm, breathing in, from “Aham”, which is “I” or “self” in Sanskrit) Sah (pronounced suh, breathing out, meaning “That” or the Divine in Sanskrit). It could also be taken as subject-object nonduality, or simply non-duality, in the New Age parlance. I am That, as translated into English. This goes a bit beyond even your question and now assumes you’re trying to reach full-blown moksha or enlightenment with kundalini yoga.

Results are not necessarily quick or blatantly obvious, in the vein of, “Whoa, I got a full-blown psychedelic/‘2001: A Space Odyssey’ fireworks-style trip from this in just 7 days!!!”, but mantra japa is highly respected by Hindu yogis as a path to enlightenment.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>34022858
From your heels, up the back of your legs, up the back of your spine, then top of your head, to make clear — there’s no sudden leaps or skips in the course of such a breathing visualization. Even aside from your question, it’s an amazingly effective way of teaching your consciousness to stay still and grounded in the present, silence your brain-chatter, and have a greater awareness of your body and your surroundings, when you remember to do it. This is why fixing awareness/attention to the breath is such a highly respected practice throughout various religious traditions — Orthodox Christians even do it as hesychast practices or the Jesus Prayer, repeated silently with the breath.

Good luck.
